Posts.Content: Dear Friends, I cannot stress enough the importance of talking with a genetics expert prior to deciding for or against genetic testing. Cancer genetics is an area of medicine which is rapidly evolving--and it's difficult for nonexperts--every physicians and oncologists to stay up-to-date on the informaiton. I strongly encourage anyone concerned about hereditary cancer or considering genetic testing to make an appointment with a genetic counselor. You can find a genetic counselor through the National Society of Genetic Counselors at http://www.nsgc.org even if you have decided not to have genetic testing, a genetic counselor can make sure that you can get the best follow-up care. And FORCE is an organization devoted to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer--feel free to peruse our resource guide and message boards. Most of the women at our site have had genetic counseling and/or testing and are happy to share their experiences. Hope this helps. Warm regards, Sue
Posts.Title: Gene Testing

Posts.Content: Hi Lorie, I had invasive ductal in one side and when I went to have a prophylactic on my other side they found DCIS. Cancer in both breasts *could* be a sign of an hereditary cancer syndrome. You might want to request a referral to a genetic counselor. You can find one through the National Society of Genetic Counselors at: http://www.nsgc.org I'm so sorry that you are dealing with this. I'm 8 years out from my diagnosis. I have a BRCA2 mutation it turns out. Feel free to e-mail me at: [email protected] Warm regards, Sue
Posts.Title: Anyone Been Dx'ed BC in Both Breasts?

Posts.Content: Dear Friends, Those of you who know me, know that I founded FORCE: Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered for hereditary breast and ovarian cancer and/or those with a BRCA mutation. Currently until Sunday night at 11:59 pm we are having our annual chat-a-thon. Our chat-room will be staffed 24 hours a day by our volunteers. It's a great chance to see what FORCE does, and say hello to our great community. You can access the chat-room at: http://www.facingourrisk.org/chat.php">http://www.facingourrisk.org/chat Hope to see some of you there. I know that several of our angels have participated in previous chats. Warm regards, Sue
Posts.Title: Come chat with us at the FORCE chat-a-thon

Posts.Content: Dear Friends, I'm pleased and excited to announce that the Joining FORCEs Conference webcast[/u][/b][/ur] is now available online at: http://www.facingourrisk.org/webcast . Access to the webcasts is free but it does require you to sign up. The conference, which was held in Tampa, Florida February 10-11 at the H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center and Research Institute featured speakers of international acclaim with expertise on BRCA and hereditary cancer. The webcasts are limited to the PowerPoint slides and audio (and a couple of sessions without slides only have the audio). Topics include: Modifiers of breast and ovarian cancer risk, ovarian and breast cancer early detection for high-risk women, ovarian cancer prevention, targeted therapy for breast cancer in BRCA carriers, reconstruction options, advocacy and other sessions. Warm regards, Sue [/url]
Posts.Title: Free webcast from conference on BRCA and hereditary cancer..

Posts.Content: Dear Friends, We now have a new survey up: For those of you who might be interested in attending this conference we are asking you to fill out a new survey to further assist us in designing our agenda. Even if you filled out the previous survey, if you could take a moment to fill out this new survey at: http://www.surveymonkey.com/s.asp?u=106151273416 it could help us in further planning this first conference. All responses are confidential unless you elect to provide an e-mail address for updates about the conference. Thanks in advance. Warm regards, Sue Friedman
Posts.Title: FORCE conference on hereditary breast and ovarian cancer--wo

Posts.Content: Dear Friends, Thanks to Lauri for the head's up about this great new forum! FORCE: Facing Our Risk of Cancer is a national nonprofit organization devoted to individuals and families affected by hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. Generally speaking, although most breast cancer is not hereditary, if there are certain red flags in the family, a hereditary component is more likely. At FORCE we always recommend that women who are concerned about their hereditary risk see an expert in cancer genetics--that is a genetic counselor. They will not try to persuade you either way but will give you up-to-date information (cancer genetics is a rapidly changing area) and help you make an informed decision. You can find a genetic counselor near you through the National Society of Genetic Counselors website at: http://www.nsgc.org I also encourage you to visit FORCE if you would like to learn more about hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. Particularly helpful is our brochure on genetic testing at: http://www.facingourrisk.org/publica...rochure604.pdf and our Resource guide with links to helpful and credible resources at: http://www.facingourrisk.org/resources.php And if you would like to talk with a community of women who have for the most part been through the genetic counseling and testing process then you might want to visit our message boards as well. I hope this helps. I'm always available if anyone would like to talk with me about my experiences. I have a BRCA2 mutation (found out after diagnosis at age 33 with breast cancer) and also I'm founded and executive director of FORCE. Warm regards, Sue [/url]
Posts.Title: BRCA1 and BRCA2

Posts.Content: Dear Friends, Forgive me that I hardly ever post here! You know that you are all in my hearts. For those of you whose cancer is hereditary (whether or not you have BRCA or have had genetic testing), FORCE is in the process of planning a national FORCE conference focused on individuals and families affected by hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. Your feedback and input is very appreciated. The conference will be held on February 10-11 in Tampa, Florida. If you could take a moment to fill out this survey at: http://www.surveymonkey.com/s.asp?u=723851259141 it could help us in planning this first conference. All responses are confidential unless you elect to provide an e-mail address for updates about the conference. Even if you are not planning to attend this meeting, we would love your feedback. Feel free to e-mail me at [email protected] if you have any questions about the conference or the survey. Thanks in advance. Warm regards, Sue
Posts.Title: FORCE conference on hereditary breast and ovarian cancer--wo
